bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, May 25, 1879

div1.p: Reed describes a carriage ride. He responds to a letter from Emilie Lawrence Reed, giving her financial advice and offering news of acquaintances.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, May 25, 1879
div1.p:
This is Sunday
morning, and as I have had a good bath, been
to sick-call and eaten my breakfast, I know
of no more pleasant duty than writing to
my own darling wife- I am expecting a real
long letter from my little darling to-day; yes
at least two of them, telling me all about
her arrival & what she has been doing with
her sweet little self & what papa's darling little
Laurie has been doing with his “ittle tef,” for
the past two weeks- (I had reached this stage of
my letter, when a chariot rolled up to the door-
“Mrs. Harrison's Compliments, and would the Doctor
like to take a ride-” well, what was to be done?
As much as I wished to continue talking
with my own little Emilie, love, I couldn't
well refuse my first invitation and that
too from Mrs. Harrison- So I accepted, put
away my letter, and Dr McPherson & I jumped
aboard- we stopped at Mrs. Compton's
casa & took her as a passenger also, & there
“all aboard” for the North Fork- we had quite
a pleasant drive & as we were fortunately
all chatty, barring the dust, our ride
was enjoyable)- I could but think of the
last time I had ridden out to the North
Fork- Then I was with my own darling
Emilie & sweet “bad daddies”- & such a long
journey as we had before us- Have you,
my little pretty bride, forgotten that terrible
journey with all its annoyances & dust &
wind & husband's crossness? Emilie, love,
my own pretty, smart wife, you don't treas-
-ure up any thing against your poor
Mantee, who is away out here in Arizona,
all by his “ittle teffie,” do you? Please
darling, forgive his crossness, this time,
& you will find that he will be a heap
sweeter & better “mantee” to you, when
he comes East- Now won't you, my “ittle”
pet? Husband gives you one sweet kiss
right on those pretty, cherry lips, and asks
your pardon! Now, you have forgiven
him haven't you? Ah! you pretty
little darling, if you haven't done so, it's
just because you want “mantee” to give you
another kiss! you pretty little, lovie, you shan't
have it though! yes, you shall! husband
takes it all back- She “sal have jes as
mausig as tee wants”- Now its alright, ain't
it, darling! you had better mind, I'll “fow
you in the teet & let the old Mexitan dit oo”!
I know something that you don't know- I guess
my little wifie would like to take a peep
into the tray of my trunk & see whose photo-
graph I've got- Two of them too, & she is just
as pretty and sweet as she can be! I just
go to my trunk every morning & evening &
give both of them a dozen kisses a piece-
Now ain't you sorry you've gone away,
and left your mantee to flirt with two other
gals! Do you know who they are? why,
nobody but “mama”, her darling little self-
Papa found them in the letter pocket in his
trunk & he was so glad to see his precious
darling again, that he just took both of them
out, gave them a good, rousing kiss & hug,
and put them in the tray of his trunk, side
by side, “right side up with care,” so that
every time he goes to his trunk, there shines
forth & beams upon him two sweet “mamas”,
& then he gives them both a darling kiss &
tells them if they don't “have deir ittle teffies”
he will “frow dem in de teet”- “Deys two mighty
dood” little gals & lots of company to papa-
And then besides, papa has too little girls-
in his trunk -- “little mamas”, when his pre-
-cious little wifie wore shoes with the
toes out! These are lots of company too-
If he only had a picture of his precious
little son to place just between your two
darling pictures, he would then have
both mother & son, so that he could go
to his trunk & have a gambol every day.
Hurry up, my little wife, & send me a pho-
-tograph of both yourself & Laurie- I am
so anxious to see my darlings! Mrs. Harri-
-son says you promised her one of “bad
daddie” & that you must be sure to send
it- She says she never hears retreat
without thinking of Lawrence & how he
used to shake his little head- Does he still
wake the hills with retreat? Now, “dood bye” my
“itsy oomsey”, a big “tiss” for you- I won't write any more till the
mail comes -- a great big “tiss” for papa's boy too-
your affect. Papa.
Monday morning, may 26th. A nice, sweet, long letter
from my darling wifie, written may 4th-
But, lovie, dear, ain't you going to write to your
poor old mantee but once in eight days!
why, my pretty E, don't treat old “hubby” that
way! However, I think I can account for
this apparent forgetfulness on the part of my
precious Emilie. Love her heart, she has seen
so much that is pretty & interesting in Norfolk
and has had so much to talk about, that the
hours & days have fled on such rapid wings
that my little darling didn't really know how
much time had gone by- Isn't it so, my pretty wife?
How happy your letter made me -- my darling. To
know that you are happy and that the faces about
you are smiling ones & that my darling Laurie
has a good kind nurse; all these things make
me just as happy as I can be, away from my loved
ones. So Pa comes to see Lawrence very often
and thinks him very fine- I can commend
his good taste- I told Altman last eve-
ning, that all the homefolks thought Law-
rence perfectly splendid- His reply was,
“if they are used to seeing fine children,
Doctor, they couldn't say anything else”.
Altman just takes it for granted that any
body with eyes will say at once that Law-
rence is a fine boy. He won't listen to
any other opinion. I am not astonished that
our little darling loves his colored mama.
you know, my darling, how he likes out-of-
door life, & you may rest assured that he
will love anybody who will take him out.
If my darling little wifie will allow a sug-
-gestion from far Arizona, I would advise
you to let his nurse dress him too- you
know, darling, how much labor you had
to do out here, & you should, my love, take
all the rest you can- Give my regards
to Aunt Mary & tell her to take good care
of Lawrence- not to spoil him, by rocking
him to sleep at night, & not to let him trou-
ble his mother any. Do you hear, my wifie?
I was so much amused & interested at what
my little wifie had to say about her nice new
grenadine or “bombazine”, I forget which. Love
your precious heart, husband knows who looked just
as pretty & sweet as an angel in that dress-
And then, next week, “see was doing to has a feet
tummer tilk” to dress in- Husbands wishes that
he had the money to dress his “feetning” wife
as fine as any other woman- you know this
don't you, darling? He had to laugh heartily at
your allusion to the money running short by
August- Poor little darling, she shall have some
more money by August- Husband says so. Now
don't borrow any, my little darling, whatever you do.
I can pay for your necklace in June & can send
you $75 out of my July pay- Now, don't forget it.
I wouldn't have you, under any circumstances,
borrow of John Vaughan or any one- Make your
money go as far as it will, & when it is running
low, I will replenish your purse- you “Sabe”?
Speaking of your necklace, when I came back
through Santa Fe, I went into Mr Luca's Store
& saw Mr Pegram & the little gentleman- Mr L. was
not in- They said that your necklace would be
made by middle of June or before- I gave them
your address as No. 66 Freemason St. Care
John Vaughan, to which address it will be
sent by express- I thought it better to have
it addressed to Norfolk, as Murfreesboro is
rather out of the way- Wasn't that right?
Tuesday morning, 8 o'clock- I have just read over
my little darling's letter for about the 10th time,
and I don't believe I've got enough of it yet- Its
the only real letter I've got from my “itsy nemp-
sy” since “sees been done”- “Boodigs”! Of course Pa
is right about my hair resembling Lawrence's-
there was a slight difference, it is true- mine
was as white as cotton and as straight as
a well conducted poker, but with the exception of this little
difference, there is a very great resemblance- we
were all, last night, at an entertainment at
the Trader's new billiard room last & had a real
pleasant evening -- didn't get into my couch
till after midnight- Mrs. Harrison & I had a
tete-a-tete during the evening -- the theme of our
conversation was my darling wife & boy-
Mrs. H. she misses you so much -- that you must be
sure to send her a photograph of Lawrence as
soon as taken- Mrs. H. & Hentig send their best love-
& Mrs. H. a kiss for baby- Mr Staples told me to tell you
that the only regret of the evening was that Mrs.
Reed was not present- He sends his kindest
regards, as well as all the others- & Now papa must
close his long letter to mama with oceans of
love & billions of kisses- Be a good little wifie,
& tell Laurie to be a good little son & not to forget papa.
Mother must give him a real good kiss for papa & then he
must give mama a good kiss for papas too- Best love to mother,
Sister, Doctor John & all the others- write very often to your devoted “hub.”
